DOC.HEAD: Blacklisted Screenwriter Ben Barzman Dead at 79
DOC.TEXT: Scriptwriter Ben Barzman, who was blacklisted during the McCarthy era and whose movie credits include ``El Cid,'' ``Back to Bataan,'' ``The Blue Max,'' and ``Z,'' has died. He was 79. Barzman died Friday after suffering a stroke. Barzman, a journalist, novelist and author of musical revues, began writing for the movies in 1943. He wrote or co-wrote the scripts of such films as ``The Boy With the Green Hair,'' ``Back to Bataan,'' ``El Cid,'' ``The Blue Max,'' ``Z,'' ``The Visit,'' ``The Fall of the Roman Empire'' and ``Heroes of Telemark.'' Some of the movies did not contain his screen credit because of the blacklist aimed at writers accused of being communist, said his wife, Norma Barzman. Barzman left the United States in 1949 for London, where his movie ``Christ in Concrete'' was being filmed. The movie, recently purchase by Home Box Office for release next year, went on to win awards at several European film festivals, but Barzman and his wife were told they were no longer welcome in McCarthy-era Hollywood. The government went on to revoke the Canadian-born Barzman's U.S. citizenship in 1954. Although the government restored his citizenship nine years later, he and his wife and seven children continued to life abroad until 1976. During that time he wrote novels and French and Italian films. His 1960 book ``Echo X'' won a Science Fiction Book-of-the-Month Award. He was honored with a Paris Cinematheque film retrospective in 1982 and the French named him an officer of the Order of the Arts and Letters in 1985. A memorial service was scheduled for Jan. 7. Survivors include his wife, children and five grandchildren.
